item.title: Shuttle Lands Safely in Florida
item.description: The shuttle ended a challenging 13-day mission to deliver a major new section to the International Space Station.
item.author: WARREN E. LEARY

item.title: Paleontologists Reconstruct a Monster Frog
item.description: Beelzebufo may be the largest frog that ever lived, weighing more than 10 pounds.
item.author: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: China Notes Pollution at Three Gorges Dam
item.description: China’s State Environmental Protection Administration said on Tuesday that water quality is barely improving in the main body of water behind the Three Gorges Dam.
item.author: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Scientists Would Turn Greenhouse Gas Into Gasoline
item.description: Two scientists are introducing a concept, which they have patriotically named Green Freedom, for removing carbon dioxide from the air and turning it back into gasoline.
item.author: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Long Nights, 90 Below. What More Could Astronomers Want?
item.description: The whitest place on Earth could be the coolest place on the planet for astronomy.
item.author: DENNIS OVERBYE

item.title: Russia’s Claim Under Polar Ice Irks American
item.description: A Russian dive that was the basis of a claim to nearly half of the Arctic seabed had American origins.
item.author: WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Satellite Shooting Is Next as Shuttle Heads Home
item.description: The shuttle Atlantis has cleared the way for a Defense Department effort to shoot down a failed spy satellite.
item.author: WARREN E. LEARY

item.title: With Oil Prices Rising, Wood Makes a Comeback
item.description: With oil prices rising people are turning to wood heat, raising concerns about the environmental impact of some older devices that are being used.
item.author: KATIE ZEZIMA

item.title: NASA Insists It Can Fix Flaw in Rocket Design
item.description: Vibrations in NASA’s new rocket may cause severe, perhaps fatal, injuries.
item.author: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Fighting Bedsores With a Team Approach
item.description: Bedsores may seem simple, but they are a serious matter for medical professionals.
item.author: AMANDA SCHAFFER

item.title: ‘Have You Ever Been in Psychotherapy, Doctor?’
item.description: A patient of one of my psychiatric residents recently caught him off guard with a challenging question: “Have you ever been in psychotherapy yourself?”
item.author: RICHARD A. FRIEDMAN, M.D.

item.title: Gentlemen, 5 Easy Steps to Living Long and Well
item.description: Five behaviors in elderly men are associated not only with living into extreme old age, a new study has found, but also with good health and independent functioning.
item.author: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Magnetic Personalities
item.description: Why won’t a magnet stick to stainless steel?
item.author: C. CLAIBORNE RAY

item.title: Support for a Theory as to Why Land Sinks Along the Gulf Coast
item.description: Understanding why land sinks may help to prevent rising water levels along the Gulf Coast.
item.author: HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Scientists Finding Ways to Perfect a Cup of Joe, Without the Attitude
item.description: A new machine may be able to judge the sensory qualities of a cup of espresso.
item.author: Henry Fountain

item.title: The Color of Victory? Rethinking the Power of a Blue Judo Uniform
item.description: Can the color of an athlete’s uniform affect success?
item.author: Henry Fountain

item.title: Prognosis: Large Social Networks May Help Surgical Patients
item.description: Having a large network of friends and family may help surgical patients experience less anxiety and pain before their operations and a quicker recovery afterward.
item.author: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Patterns: A Video Game, an M.R.I. and What Men’s Brains Do
item.description: Why does it often seem that men enjoy playing video games more than women? Perhaps because they do.
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Regimens: Diet Supplement Seen as Risky for Some Users
item.description: Probiotics, the potentially beneficial bacteria and yeasts available as diet supplements, may not be as helpful as widely believed.
item.author: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Behavior: An Absence of Free Will, a Tendency to Cheat
item.description: If there is no such thing as free will, do you really have to put that money into the office coffee kitty when no one is looking?
item.author: ERIC NAGOURNEY

item.title: Decoding Human Rapport (1 Letter)
item.description: To the Editor:.

item.title: Of Couples and Romance (1 Letter)
item.description: To the Editor:.

item.title: The Early Lure of Tobacco (2 Letters)
item.description: To the Editor:.

item.title: Verifying a Diagnosis (1 Letter)
item.description: To the Editor:.

item.title: Revealed: Secrets of the Camouflage Masters
item.description: After decades of dives, a scientist offers a theory to explain the spectacular deceptions of cephalopods.
item.author: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Lowering Odds of Multiple Births
item.description: In the world of fertility treatment, doctors are sounding a call to arms to reverse the soaring rate of multiple births.
item.author: LAURIE TARKAN

item.title: What People Owe Fish: A Lot
item.description: Feel like a fish out of water? You may not be too far off.
item.author: NATALIE ANGIER

item.title: An Oldie Vies for Nutrient of the Decade
item.description: Researchers are trying to understand how much vitamin D is necessary for optimal health. Are you taking enough?
item.author: JANE E. BRODY

item.title: The Claim: Honey Can Soothe a Burn
item.description: Home remedies for soothing mild burns run the gamut, from aloe vera gel to butter, but how does honey fare?
item.author: ANAHAD O’CONNOR
